text: I follow Alicia outside. The morning light is sharp; meltwater drips from the eaves, and the street reflects a silvery glare.
She walks quickly, but not in a rush—more like someone familiar with the procedure. At every intersection, she turns without even glancing at the signs.
“You know these roads a little too well.”
“Mm.”
“Don’t stop near the tree line. Something will crawl out of the ground.”
She says it like she’s reminding me not to step in a puddle. I almost laugh on instinct—but I can’t.
The town market is lively, as if nothing has happened. Shouts of vendors, hoofbeats, the scent of oil and bread all blend together.
Alicia doesn’t bargain. She names exactly what she wants. When the vendor tries to haggle, one look from her makes him instantly change his price.
“Three vials of coagulant, two antidotes. For the sealing talismans, I want old paper—don’t give me fresh ink.”
“…You even care whether the talisman paper is old or new?”
“Fresh ink attracts things that shouldn’t come.”
She stuffs everything into my arms in one motion. The weight makes my shoulders ache.
On the way back to the tavern, we pass a stone path near the pine woods. The wind makes the treetops creak; the air is sharp as a blade.
Just as I’m about to quicken my pace, there’s a dull thud beneath my feet—like something turning over in the soil.
The earth splits open. A beast with a stone-plated back crawls out, its blue-lit eyes fixed on us.
“This… is what you meant?”
“Don’t move.”
She doesn’t even draw her sword yet. She just tugs her glove up half an inch, like she’s about to start some ordinary task.
“On the third step, it’ll lunge at you.”
“How do you—”
The beast growls. One step. Two. Three—then it lunges!
“See?”
She finally draws her sword, the movement swift as wind slicing across snow. A flash of silver—its front claw is severed cleanly.
The second strike is even cleaner, like cutting through wood whose grain she has long memorized. The stone shell shatters; the blue light dies instantly.
The beast collapses, its body dissolving into a wisp of black smoke that sinks back into the earth. Only a scorched ring remains on the ground.
“You… made that look way too easy.”
“That was just a small one.”
“Let’s go. Don’t stare.”
